item.title: Hogwarts Legacy Just Did Something Only A Small Group Of Games Ever Have
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

By on December 17, 2025 at 1:13PM PST

The Harry Potter game Hogwarts Legacy has now sold more than 40 million copies worldwide, making it among the best-selling games of all time.

Warner Bros. Games made the announcement today, December 17, amid its parent company Warner Bros. Discovery's sale to Netflix, or Paramount. At 40 million sales, the game is a smash hit, but not quite close enough to break into the top 10 best-selling games ever.

Hogwarts Legacy was developed by Avalanche Software and published by Warner Bros. Games through its Portkey Games label, which handles Harry Potter games for the company.

Hogwarts Legacy is set in the 1800s with players coming to Hogwarts as a fifth-year student as they learn spells and tame magical creatures. The game outsold Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III in North America in 2023, and that's a rare thing given how dominant Call of Duty has been.

Unsurprisingly, Warner Bros. Games has said making a sequel is a major priority for the company, though the follow-up has yet to be formally announced. Another major fantasy franchise, Lord of the Rings, is said to be getting a Hogwarts Legacy-style game in the future.

Hogwarts Legacy has been embroiled in controversy due to transphobic remarks from Harry Potter author JK Rowling. Although she is not personally involved with its development, she stands to profit from its success. For more, read our in-depth article on how Rowling's comments have impacted the trans community. In this article, you will also find links to trans creators you can support, as well as charities you can donate to.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Game Awards Reaches New Viewership Milestone In 2025, Higher Than Super Bowl Numbers
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Game Awards had another strong year in 2025, with host and organizer Geoff Keighley announcing today that the show reached 171 million global livestreams. That's up 11% from 154 million in 2024 and makes the 2025 show the "most watched TGA in history."

Keighley also states that conversations about TGA on X were up 12% and that the show had 23,000 co-streams across Twitch and YouTube, which was up 50% year-over-year. The new streaming viewership numbers do not count views on Prime Video, Variety reported.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: The Best Game Awards 2025 Trailers

This year's Super Bowl, meanwhile, reached 127.7 million viewers. The comparison is not 1:1, however, for many reasons.

The Game Awards 2025 had a bunch of big, exciting announcements, including Larian's next game, Divinity, along with Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic, and a new shooter called Highguard. Many awards were handed out as well, including Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 winning Game of the Year.

The Sandfall-developed game was the biggest winner of the night, scoring nine total wins and breaking The Game Awards records.

Keighley is expected to bring back The Game Awards in December 2026, but his next event will be Summer Game Fest in June 2026.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Silent Hill F Producer Hints At Future Sequels Set Outside Of US
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Earlier this year, Silent Hill f became the first game in the series to ditch the small American town that the series was named for in favor of setting it in Japan decades earlier. That approach may be used again for future titles in the franchise, according to developer Motoi Okamoto.

"We believe we could perhaps take similar approaches with other cultures across the globe," Okamoto told Inverse through a translator. "For example, in Central or South America, we could perhaps tap into the more local, shamanistic beliefs and see how that ties in. But we could also try to expand our horizons and look into other regions, like possibly Russia, Italy, or South Korea, because all those areas have their own unique types of belief systems. I believe that will be a gateway for us to expand our concepts further."

Okamoto appears to have put the most thought into the Central and South American locations, which he said have "been affected by a lot of military governments and coups," before adding, "There is a type of bravado and 'machismo' that comes from these political landscapes. Thereâ€™s also the more folkloric angle coming from shamanism and local beliefs."

However, Okamoto noted that Konami potentially partnering with a development studio in Central and South America for a Silent Hill game may be difficult because the region doesn't have many to choose from. But he didn't rule it out.

Okamoto recently credited memes and fan art for keeping Silent Hill f trending months after its release. An update for that game also added a new casual difficulty and a skip feature for new game plus. Meanwhile, the Silent Hill 2 remake appears to have been quietly confirmed for Xbox Series X|S. Microsoft and Konami have yet to announce a release for that port.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Call Of Duty Is Crossing Over With Fallout TV Show In Season 1 Reloaded
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Season 1 of Black Ops 7 and Warzone is currently underway, and now Activision has announced Call of Duty's crossover with Amazon Prime Video's Fallout TV show for the midseason update.

Activision released a very brief teaser clip for Black Ops 7 and Warzone to reveal the operator skins for this upcoming crossover. While you can't see the full details of the operator skins, the silhouettes clearly hint at operators for Lucy, The Ghoul, and Maximus in his power armor. Call of Duty's big IP collaborations also usually come packed with events for players to participate in. It's uncertain if the skins will be included in an event pass or as shop bundles for purchase.

Call of Duty's paid event passes are usually 1,100 CoD Points ($10) and operator packs usually feature a price of 2,800 CoD Points ($25) for each bundle.

This collaboration is well-timed with the debut of the Fallout TV show's second season, which began on December 16. This will be the first major collaboration to appear in Black Ops 7, as Activision cancelled plans for Call of Duty's Carry Forward program, preventing Black Ops 6 skins like Beavis and Butt-Head from joining the operator lineup for the game.

Activision's initial statement said it understood that people want Call of Duty to be and feel "immersive, intense, visceral and in many ways grounded." However, the statement didn't confirm the future plans for operator skins, and the authenticity of the game seems to only apply for the launch window of Black Ops 7.

Season 1's midseason update arrives sometime after the holidays. In addition to the Fallout operator skins, Call of Duty's Season 1 Reloaded update will also add more maps, modes, and challenges.

Black Ops 7 currently features a free trial across all platforms. From now until December 22, players can access 20+ maps and experience the Ashes of the Damned map for Zombies. For Fallout fans, Fallout 76 is also free-to-play for a limited time on PS5 and Xbox Series X|S.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
